docs.lead_paragraph: The State of Michigan asked the Clinton Administration today for permission to undertake a vast welfare overhaul whose central provision would require work in exchange for benefits. This afternoon the state delivered to the Federal Department of Health and Human Services an inch-high stack of documents requesting the necessary waivers -- 75 exemptions in all -- that would allow it to deviate from the Government's welfare rules.

headline.main: Michigan Asks U.S. to Approve Work-for-Welfare Plan

docs.lead_paragraph: The Clinton Administration signaled this week that it is prepared to approve New York's ambitious plan to place nearly three million more poor people into managed care programs, but indicated that it would do so only if the state first satisfied several concerns about the availability and quality of the medical care. President Clinton has approved similar programs in 12 other states, but the one proposed by Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, would be by far the largest and most sweeping. Except for the elderly, nearly all people who receive Medicaid, the health insurance plan for the poor, would be required to enroll in a managed care plan or risk losing their medical coverage -- a move the Governor hopes will ultimately save hundreds of millions of dollars for the state, New York City and other localities.

headline.main: CLINTON EXPECTED TO SUPPORT PATAKI ON MEDICAID SHIFT

docs.lead_paragraph: Congressional Democrats are at a critical transition in their struggle to regain control of the House. They have prospered in the polls, so far, with a full-throated attack on the Republican agenda. Now, in a campaign begun this week after months of planning and research, Democrats are trying to redefine their own party and convince the voters that it deserves another chance in power. The effort revolves around Families First, a party agenda jointly produced by Democrats in the Senate and the House, in consultation with the White House, two years after the elections that cost their party control of Congress. Democratic leaders describe the document as an intentionally modest set of proposals to help the average American family, ranging from new tax credits for college education to incentives to expand private health insurance coverage for children.

headline.main: Democrats' New Goal in Congress: Modesty

docs.lead_paragraph: More than 30 Catholic hospitals and nursing homes in the New York region are banding together in a new health care network intended to help its members compete in an era of managed care and to strengthen the church's mission of treating the poor. The Archdiocese of New York is expected to announce today the formation of the Catholic Health Care Network of New York, which will serve 2.5 million patients a year from Staten Island to Poughkeepsie.

headline.main: In Health Care's New Era, Catholic Institutions Link Up to Compete

docs.lead_paragraph: United Wisconsin Services Inc. signed a letter of intent yesterday to acquire American Medical Security Group Inc. for about $156 million, consisting of $67.2 million in cash and 4 million newly issued shares. Shares of United Wisconsin rose 50 cents, to $22.375, on the New York Stock Exchange before the deal was announced. The privately held American Medical is United's partner in a small group health insurance business. United, a managed health care concern based in Milwaukee, owns 12 percent of American Medical.

headline.main: UNITED WISCONSIN AGREES TO ACQUIRE A PARTNER

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A June 20 letter accuses U.S. Healthcare of denying a child a heart transplant. Our National Medical Excellence program coordinates care for transplant patients. We cover transplants recommended by recognized transplant centers. We do not deny coverage for needed transplants.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Occidental Chemical Corporation, whose corporate predecessor was responsible for polluting the Love Canal in New York State, will receive an undisclosed portion of the estimated $1 billion in cleanup costs under a settlement with Lloyd's of London. Justice James Kane of State Supreme Court confirmed today that the largest part of a case between Occidental and Lloyd's, the world's largest insurance syndicate, had been completed. The lawsuit was filed in 1980.

docs.lead_paragraph: TWO familiar advertising figures and a politician turned product peddler are featured in new pitches for consumer brands that epitomize the appeal of continuing characters in marketers' campaigns. Fred, the diligent Dunkin' Donuts baker who dutifully drives himself with the mantra "Time to make the doughnuts," is branching out as that company begins adding bagels to its menu of baked goods. In commercials by Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG, Fred visits New York for focus-group interviews, seeking opinions from picky local bagel noshers. In addition to the requisite cab drivers and cops, Fred, portrayed by Michael Vale, encounters Edward I. Koch, the former Mayor who has developed a post-political career as an advertising star.

headline.main: New campaigns by Dunkin' Donuts and Wendy's use familiar faces to build loyalty.

docs.lead_paragraph: Holding hands, the First Couple strode onto the stage today under posters of a child's line drawing of a house. Holding hands, the Second Couple followed. Like the bus trips of 1992, it was a Clinton-Gore extravaganza, at the Gores' annual conference on family and work. There was talk of "good fathers like Bill Clinton and Al Gore." Of the "family-friendly workplace." Of "a brand new way of thinking about the wholeness of our lives." There were video clips of family scenes from television to the movies, from the idyllic to the most strained.

headline.main: Banking on Family Issues, Clinton Seeks Parents' Votes
